canonical_explanation.text: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns. A matrix with m rows and n columns has order m×n. Two matrices can be added only if they have the same order. Matrix multiplication AB is defined when the number of columns of A equals the number of rows of B, giving a matrix of order (rows of A)×(columns of B). Matrix multiplication is not commutative in general. The transpose A' is obtained by interchanging rows and columns.
rules: Matrix multiplication is distributive: A(B+C) = AB + AC
Every square matrix A can be written as ½(A+A') + ½(A-A') where ½(A+A') is symmetric and ½(A-A') is skew-symmetric
AI = IA = A where I is the identity matrix

questions.question_text: A matrix having 3 rows and 2 columns is of order:
questions.explanation_correct: The order of a matrix is written as m×n where m is the number of rows and n is the number of columns. With 3 rows and 2 columns, the order is 3×2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the convention (rows×columns). Option C gives the total number of elements, not the order. Option D would require equal rows and columns.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a scalar matrix?
questions.explanation_correct: A scalar matrix is a diagonal matrix in which all diagonal elements are equal. In [[3, 0], [0, 3]], all diagonal elements are 3 and all non-diagonal elements are 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is diagonal but not scalar since diagonal elements 1 and 2 are different. Option C is not even diagonal. Option D has zeros on the diagonal and non-zeros off the diagonal.

questions.question_text: The number of elements in a matrix of order 3×2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: A matrix of order m×n has m×n elements. So a 3×2 matrix has 3×2 = 6 elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A gives the sum 3+2, not the product. Option C gives only the number of rows. Option D would be for a 3×3 matrix.

questions.question_text: A matrix with only one row is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A matrix having only one row (order 1×n) is called a row matrix or row vector.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A column matrix has only one column. A square matrix has equal rows and columns. A diagonal matrix is a square matrix with non-zero entries only on the main diagonal.

questions.question_text: Two matrices A and B can be added only if they have the same order.
questions.explanation_correct: Matrix addition is defined only for matrices of the same order. Corresponding elements are added, which requires both matrices to have the same number of rows and columns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Matrices of different orders cannot be added because there would be no corresponding element for some entries.

questions.explanation_correct: A + B is found by adding corresponding elements: [[2+1, 3+0], [4+(−1), 5+2]] = [[3, 3], [3, 7]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B has an incorrect (2,1) entry: 4+(−1) = 3, not 5. Option C subtracts instead of adding in some entries. Option D has incorrect entries.

questions.question_text: If A = [[1, 2], [3, 4]], then 3A equals:
questions.explanation_correct: Scalar multiplication multiplies every element by the scalar: 3A = [[3×1, 3×2], [3×3, 3×4]] = [[3, 6], [9, 12]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B only multiplied the first column. Option C adds 3 to each element instead of multiplying. Option D only multiplied some elements.

questions.question_text: The identity matrix of order 2 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The identity matrix I of order 2 has 1s on the main diagonal and 0s elsewhere: I₂ = [[1, 0], [0, 1]]. It satisfies AI = IA = A for any 2×2 matrix A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A has all entries as 1. Option C has 1s on the anti-diagonal, not the main diagonal. Option D has a 0 on the diagonal.

questions.question_text: If A is a matrix of order 2×3 and B is a matrix of order 3×4, then the order of AB is:
questions.explanation_correct: If A is m×p and B is p×n, then AB is m×n. Here A is 2×3 and B is 3×4, so AB is 2×4. The inner dimensions (3) must match, and the outer dimensions (2 and 4) give the order of the product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B uses the inner dimensions. Option C gives the order of A, not AB. Option D reverses the outer dimensions.

questions.question_text: For which of the following pairs is the product AB defined? A is 3×2 and B is:
questions.explanation_correct: AB is defined when the number of columns of A equals the number of rows of B. A has 2 columns, so B must have 2 rows. Only the 2×3 matrix has 2 rows.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and C have 3 rows, and Option D has 1 row. None of these match the 2 columns of A.
Option B is just A itself. Option C is the element-wise product (Hadamard product), not matrix multiplication. Option D has an incorrect (2,1) entry.

questions.question_text: Matrix multiplication is commutative, i.e., AB = BA for all matrices A and B.
questions.explanation_correct: Matrix multiplication is NOT commutative in general. AB ≠ BA in most cases. For example, with A = [[1, 0], [0, 0]] and B = [[0, 1], [0, 0]], AB = [[0, 1], [0, 0]] but BA = [[0, 0], [0, 0]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Matrix multiplication does not satisfy the commutative property in general, unlike addition of matrices or multiplication of real numbers.

questions.question_text: A zero matrix of order 2×3 has:
questions.explanation_correct: A zero matrix (also called null matrix) is a matrix in which all elements are zero. A 2×3 zero matrix is [[0, 0, 0], [0, 0, 0]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A describes a matrix of all ones. Option C only mentions diagonal elements. Option D is incorrect as the matrix has 6 elements, all equal to zero.

questions.explanation_correct: The (1,1) entry of A − B is the (1,1) entry of A minus the (1,1) entry of B: 2 − 4 = −2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B gives the sum 2+4. Option C gives the entry of A. Option D is incorrect arithmetic.

questions.question_text: Two matrices A = [[a, b], [c, d]] and B = [[1, 2], [3, 4]] are equal. What is the value of a + d?
questions.explanation_correct: Two matrices are equal if and only if their corresponding elements are equal. So a = 1, b = 2, c = 3, d = 4. Therefore a + d = 1 + 4 = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A gives a + b (wrong pair). Option C gives d alone. Option D gives a + b + d incorrectly.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a diagonal matrix?
questions.explanation_correct: A diagonal matrix is a square matrix where all non-diagonal elements are zero. In [[5, 0], [0, −3]], the off-diagonal entries are both 0, so it is diagonal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A has non-zero off-diagonal elements 2 and 3. Option C has a non-zero entry at position (1,2). Option D has a non-zero entry at position (2,1).

questions.question_text: If A = [[1, 2], [3, 4]] and B = [[2, 0], [1, 3]], then AB − BA equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A would mean AB = BA, which is not the case here. Option C is BA − AB (signs reversed). Option D has incorrect signs.

questions.question_text: The transpose of the matrix A = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]] is:
questions.explanation_correct: The transpose A' is obtained by interchanging rows and columns. Row 1 of A becomes column 1 of A', and row 2 of A becomes column 2 of A'. So A' = [[1, 4], [2, 5], [3, 6]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B reverses the elements. Option C rearranges elements incorrectly. Option D simply swaps the two rows without transposing.

questions.question_text: If A is a matrix of order 3×2, then the order of A' (transpose of A) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The transpose of an m×n matrix is an n×m matrix. So the transpose of a 3×2 matrix is a 2×3 matrix.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A gives the same order as A. Options C and D give square matrix orders that don't follow from transposing a 3×2 matrix.

questions.question_text: A square matrix A is symmetric if:
questions.explanation_correct: A square matrix A is symmetric if its transpose equals itself, i.e., A' = A. This means aᵢⱼ = aⱼᵢ for all i and j.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A defines a skew-symmetric matrix. Option C defines an idempotent matrix. Option D defines an orthogonal matrix.

questions.question_text: Which of the following matrices is skew-symmetric?
questions.explanation_correct: A matrix is skew-symmetric if A' = −A. For [[0, 2], [−2, 0]], its transpose is [[0, −2], [2, 0]] = −[[0, 2], [−2, 0]]. Also, the diagonal elements of a skew-symmetric matrix must be 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is symmetric (A' = A). Option C is also symmetric. Option D is neither symmetric nor skew-symmetric.
Option B has an incorrect first entry (should be 3, not 4). Option C has an incorrect second entry (should be 5, not 4). Option D reverses the entries.

questions.question_text: If A = [[2, −1], [3, 4]] and I is the 2×2 identity matrix, then A − 2I equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B did not subtract 2 from the (2,2) entry. Option C subtracts 2 from all entries incorrectly. Option D adds 2I instead of subtracting.

questions.question_text: If A = [[1, 2], [3, 4]], then A + A' equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B simply doubles A (which is 2A, not A+A'). Option C is A − A'. Option D has wrong diagonal entries.

questions.question_text: If A = [[3, 1], [−1, 2]], then A − A' equals:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is A + A'. Option C has the signs reversed (it is A' − A). Option D would mean A is symmetric, which it is not.

questions.question_text: The diagonal elements of a skew-symmetric matrix are always zero.
questions.explanation_correct: For a skew-symmetric matrix, A' = −A, which means aᵢⱼ = −aⱼᵢ. For diagonal elements, i = j, so aᵢᵢ = −aᵢᵢ, giving 2aᵢᵢ = 0, hence aᵢᵢ = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Since aᵢᵢ = −aᵢᵢ implies aᵢᵢ = 0, all diagonal elements must be zero.

questions.question_text: For any two square matrices A and B of the same order, (A+B)(A−B) equals:
questions.explanation_correct: Using the distributive property: (A+B)(A−B) = A(A−B) + B(A−B) = A² − AB + BA − B². Since matrix multiplication is not commutative, AB ≠ BA in general, so the middle terms do not cancel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A incorrectly assumes AB = BA (commutativity). Option C has the wrong signs on the middle terms. Option D has both middle terms negative, which is incorrect.
Option B has incorrect off-diagonal entries. Option C has wrong (1,1) entry. Option D has wrong (2,2) entry.

questions.question_text: Express the matrix A = [[4, 2], [6, 8]] as the sum of a symmetric and a skew-symmetric matrix. The symmetric part is:
questions.explanation_correct: The symmetric part is ½(A + A'). A' = [[4, 6], [2, 8]]. A + A' = [[8, 8], [8, 16]]. ½(A + A') = [[4, 4], [4, 8]], which is symmetric since (1,2) = (2,1) = 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is the original matrix A. Option C is the skew-symmetric part ½(A − A'). Option D is half of A, not the symmetric part.

questions.question_text: If A = [[4, 2], [6, 8]], the skew-symmetric part ½(A − A') equals [[0, k], [−k, 0]]. The value of k is ___.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A has the wrong sign. Option C uses A − A' without the factor ½. Option D uses A − A' without ½ and wrong sign.

questions.explanation_correct: For a diagonal matrix, A² is obtained by squaring each diagonal element. A² = diag(1², 2², 3²) = [[1, 0, 0], [0, 4, 0], [0, 0, 9]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B doubles diagonal entries instead of squaring. Option C has a wrong (3,3) entry (6 instead of 9). Option D is A itself, not A².
Option B is A itself. Option C has wrong (2,2) entry. Option D has wrong diagonal entries.
Option B is AB itself, not its transpose. Option C rearranges entries incorrectly. Option D has an incorrect (2,1) entry.

questions.question_text: A square matrix A is invertible if there exists a matrix B such that:
questions.explanation_correct: A square matrix A is invertible (or non-singular) if there exists a matrix B such that AB = BA = I, where I is the identity matrix. The matrix B is called the inverse of A, denoted A⁻¹.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A means B acts as a right identity for A, not an inverse. Option B is also not the definition. Option D describes an additive relationship, not a multiplicative inverse.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elementary row operations is valid?
questions.explanation_correct: Interchanging two rows (Rᵢ ↔ Rⱼ) is a valid elementary row operation. The three elementary row operations are: (1) interchange two rows, (2) multiply a row by a non-zero scalar, (3) add a scalar multiple of one row to another row.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B uses k = 0, but the scalar must be non-zero for row scaling. Option C would destroy information and is not an elementary operation. Option D changes the size of the matrix and is not an elementary operation.

questions.question_text: The inverse of the identity matrix I is:
questions.explanation_correct: Since I·I = I, the identity matrix is its own inverse: I⁻¹ = I.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A: the zero matrix has no inverse. Option B: I·(2I) = 2I ≠ I. Option D: I·(−I) = −I ≠ I.

questions.question_text: If A is an invertible matrix, then (A⁻¹)⁻¹ = A.
questions.explanation_correct: Since AA⁻¹ = I, by definition of inverse, A is the inverse of A⁻¹. Therefore (A⁻¹)⁻¹ = A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. From the relation AA⁻¹ = A⁻¹A = I, we see that A is the inverse of A⁻¹.

questions.question_text: Using elementary row operations, if we apply R₂ → R₂ − 2R₁ to the matrix [[1, 3], [2, 7]], we get:
questions.explanation_correct: R₂ → R₂ − 2R₁: New R₂ = [2−2×1, 7−2×3] = [0, 1]. The matrix becomes [[1, 3], [0, 1]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B has wrong (2,2) entry (7−6=1, not 4). Option C adds 2R₁ instead of subtracting. Option D only modifies the (2,2) entry.

questions.question_text: Find the inverse of A = [[2, 1], [5, 3]] using the formula A⁻¹ = (1/det A) × adj(A).

questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A would be correct if A were the identity. Option C and D do not follow from any property of identity matrix multiplication.

questions.question_text: If A is a 3×3 symmetric matrix and B is a 3×3 skew-symmetric matrix, then the matrix AB − BA is:

options.text: Neither symmetric nor skew-symmetric in general

questions.explanation_correct: (AB − BA)' = (AB)' − (BA)' = B'A' − A'B' = (−B)(A) − (A)(−B) = −BA + AB = AB − BA. Since (AB − BA)' = AB − BA, the matrix is symmetric.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because the transpose equals itself, not its negative. Option C is incorrect; AB − BA is not necessarily zero. Option D is incorrect; we proved it is always symmetric.

questions.question_text: If A = [[1, 1], [0, 1]], then A¹⁰ equals:
questions.explanation_correct: A = I + N where N = [[0, 1], [0, 0]]. N² = [[0,0],[0,0]] = O. By induction (or binomial theorem for matrices since IN = NI), Aⁿ = I + nN = [[1, n], [0, 1]]. So A¹⁰ = [[1, 10], [0, 1]]. Verify: A² = [[1,2],[0,1]], A³ = [[1,3],[0,1]], confirming the pattern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is A¹, not A¹⁰. Option C scales diagonal entries. Option D uses 2¹⁰ = 1024, confusing exponentiation of entries with matrix power.

questions.question_text: If A is a square matrix such that A² = A, then (I + A)³ − 7A equals:
questions.explanation_correct: Since A² = A (idempotent), we also get A³ = A²·A = A·A = A² = A. Expand (I+A)³ = I³ + 3I²A + 3IA² + A³ = I + 3A + 3A + A = I + 7A. (We can use the binomial expansion since I and A commute.) So (I+A)³ − 7A = I + 7A − 7A = I.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, B, and D result from errors in expansion or not using the property A² = A correctly.

questions.question_text: If A = [[1, 2], [3, 7]], find A⁻¹ using elementary row operations.

questions.question_text: If A and B are invertible matrices of the same order, then (AB)⁻¹ equals:
questions.explanation_correct: (AB)(B⁻¹A⁻¹) = A(BB⁻¹)A⁻¹ = AIA⁻¹ = AA⁻¹ = I. Similarly (B⁻¹A⁻¹)(AB) = I. Therefore (AB)⁻¹ = B⁻¹A⁻¹. Note the reversal of order.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A does not reverse the order. Options C and D mix inverse and non-inverse incorrectly.

questions.explanation_correct: The (2,1) entry of AB = (row 2 of A)·(column 1 of B) = 3×0 + 4×1 = 0 + 4 = 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is the (1,1) entry of AB. Option B is the (2,1) entry of A, not AB. Option D is incorrect arithmetic.

questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A: A' ≠ A. Option C: the matrix has non-zero off-diagonal entries. Option D: a scalar matrix has equal diagonal entries and zero off-diagonal entries.
Option B is adj(A) without dividing by det(A). Option C has entries arranged incorrectly. Option D has sign errors.

questions.explanation_correct: For diagonal matrices, the product is also diagonal with entries being the products of corresponding diagonal entries: diag(2×1, 3×4, 5×2) = diag(2, 12, 10) = [[2, 0, 0], [0, 12, 0], [0, 0, 10]].
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B adds diagonal entries instead of multiplying. Option C mixes addition and multiplication. Option D has wrong (3,3) entry.

questions.question_text: If A is an invertible matrix and A² = I (the identity matrix), then A⁻¹ equals ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Given A² = I, multiply both sides on the right by A⁻¹: A²A⁻¹ = IA⁻¹, which gives A(AA⁻¹) = A⁻¹, so A·I = A⁻¹, hence A⁻¹ = A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A: A⁻¹ = I would mean A = I, which is not necessarily true. Option C: (−A) is not the inverse unless A = −I. Option D: A² = I, so A⁻¹ = A, not A².
